elements.title: Flexibility-First Search Results with Match Quality Scoring
elements.problem: Tyler's search parameters include both hard constraints (Chelsea location, ~$2000 budget, private bathroom) and soft constraints (Saturday-Wednesday ideal but flexible to Sunday-Thursday). The current platform shows listings as a flat list with no indication of how well each listing matches the guest's specific day requirements. The agent spent the entire call extracting and mentally computing match quality — work that the information architecture should do automatically. Eyal's Action principle (Ch 3) requires reducing brain cycles: the guest should not have to mentally compute 'does this listing's available days overlap with my preferred days?'
elements.solution: Structure search results to communicate match quality visually and immediately: (1) PRIMARY: Match score for each listing — a simple percentage or visual indicator showing how well the listing's available days overlap with the guest's preferred days. 'This space matches 5 of your 5 ideal nights' vs. '3 of 5 nights match — available Sunday-Wednesday.' (2) SECONDARY: Price per matched night — not just nightly rate, but cost for the guest's specific day pattern. (3) TERTIARY: Flexibility bonus — show what the guest gains by being flexible: 'If you shift to Sunday-Wednesday, this space becomes available at $1,750/month.' The information hierarchy should be: Match Quality → Price for Your Pattern → Flexibility Upside → Space Details.

evidence.quote: She was saying for Mondays to Friday and you have a little different requirements.
evidence.insight: Day mismatch between listing availability and guest needs is the primary matching problem. The IA must surface this mismatch immediately, not after a phone call.

evidence.quote: That sounds much better because now I have something to work with.
evidence.insight: The agent needed to understand flexibility to compute match quality. The platform should do this computation and present it visually.

evidence.quote: Reducing the thinking required to take the next action increases the likelihood of the desired behavior occurring unconsciously.
evidence.insight: Match scores reduce the brain cycles needed to evaluate listings. Instead of reading each listing's available days and mentally comparing, the guest sees a score.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Match quality is primary (biggest, most visible). Price for the guest's specific pattern is secondary. Space details are tertiary. This inverts the typical listing card hierarchy (photo → price → details) because for nights-of-the-week housing, day availability is the make-or-break criterion.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show match score and price on the search results card (no click required). Reveal flexibility bonuses on hover or tap. Full space details on listing page click-through.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 data points visible on search result card: match score, monthly price for guest's pattern, and location. All other details (amenities, photos, host info) available on click-through.
scan_order: Price for guest's specific pattern ('$1,900/month for your Sat-Wed schedule')
exclude: Raw nightly rate without context of guest's day pattern
Host availability calendar (too complex for search results)
Amenity lists (save for listing detail page)
Reviews and ratings (secondary to match quality for initial search)

elements.title: Price Transparency with Day-Based Decomposition
elements.problem: Tyler anchored on $1800/month (Nina's posted price for Mon-Fri) but his different day requirements (Saturday-Wednesday, including weekends) may change the price. The agent noted 'weekends usually more expensive' (11:06). Tyler said 'around 2000... don't push up the price' (11:27-12:07). There is a critical information asymmetry: the guest sees one posted price but doesn't understand how days-of-week affect pricing. When the price changes during negotiation, it feels like a bait-and-switch rather than a rational adjustment. Eyal's Variable Reward theory (Ch 4) warns that rewards must feel positive — price increases during the funnel feel like anti-rewards.
elements.solution: Structure pricing information to make day-based pricing transparent from the first touchpoint: (1) On the listing page, show a day-of-week pricing matrix: each night has a visible rate. Weekends may be marked as 'premium' or 'off-peak.' (2) When the guest selects their preferred days, show an instant price calculation: 'Saturday ($55/night) + Sunday ($55/night) + Monday ($40/night) + Tuesday ($40/night) + Wednesday ($40/night) = $270/week = $1,080/4 weeks.' (3) Show the comparison: 'Nina's posted rate ($1,800/mo) is for Mon-Fri. Your Sat-Wed pattern is $X/mo because weekends are included.' This makes price differences feel rational, not arbitrary. The information hierarchy should be: Your Total → Per-Night Breakdown → Comparison to Posted Rate.

evidence.insight: Guest anchored on posted price. Any deviation must be explained with clear decomposition, not just a new number.
Day-based pricing variation exists but is not visible to the guest. This creates surprise and erodes trust.

evidence.quote: Autonomy is essential — forced loops backfire.
evidence.insight: The guest must feel in control of pricing. Showing the decomposition lets them adjust days to hit their budget target, maintaining autonomy.

evidence.quote: Don't push up the price without a reason.
evidence.insight: Price increases feel like deception without transparent decomposition. The guest explicitly requests honesty.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Guest's total monthly cost is primary (biggest number). Per-night breakdown is secondary (explains the total). Comparison to base posted rate is tertiary (contextualizes any difference). Never show the host's posted rate without showing the guest's calculated rate alongside it.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show guest's total on listing card. Show per-night breakdown on listing detail page when guest selects days. Show rate comparison and savings opportunities on proposal review screen.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 numbers visible at once: total monthly, per-night average, number of nights, and any weekend premium indicator. Full decomposition available on expand/tap.
scan_order: Guest's monthly total for their specific pattern
Savings opportunity if guest shifts days
exclude: Raw host pricing that doesn't reflect guest's day selection
Commission/fee breakdowns on the search results page

elements.title: Guest Requirements Profile as Persistent Navigation Element
elements.problem: During the call, Tyler stated his requirements piecemeal: location at 09:26, days at 07:03, budget at 10:14, duration at 08:09, bathroom at 12:37, cleaning at 14:13, occupancy at 13:30. The agent assembled these into a mental model over 15 minutes. On the platform, these requirements must be visible and editable throughout the search and proposal flow — not scattered across separate pages or hidden after initial entry. Eyal's Investment principle (Ch 5) shows that visible stored value increases commitment and switching costs.
elements.solution: Display the guest's requirements as a persistent, collapsible summary that follows them through search, listing evaluation, and proposal creation: (1) Show a compact 'Your Search' sidebar or header strip with key parameters: 'Chelsea | Sat-Wed | ~$2,000/mo | Dec-Jan+ | Private bath.' (2) Make each parameter tappable to edit inline — changing a parameter immediately updates search results. (3) When viewing a listing, show match/mismatch indicators next to each requirement: green check for match, yellow warning for partial match, red X for conflict. (4) Carry the profile forward into proposal creation — the proposal form should be pre-filled from the profile. This makes the guest's investment visible and useful at every step, not just at data entry.

evidence.source: Tyler Wood call, full call structure
evidence.quote: Agent extracts location (09:26), days (07:03), budget (10:14), duration (08:09), bathroom (12:37), cleaning preference (14:13), and occupancy (13:30) across a 15-minute call.
evidence.insight: Requirements are extracted linearly over time but need to be presented as a unified profile. The IA must aggregate what the phone call spread across 15 minutes.

evidence.quote: Content, data, followers, reputation, skill = stored value.
evidence.insight: The guest's requirements profile IS stored data. Making it visible shows the guest what they've invested, increasing switching costs.

evidence.quote: Six elements of simplicity: time, money, physical effort, brain cycles, social deviance, non-routine.
evidence.insight: A persistent requirements profile reduces brain cycles on every subsequent page — the guest doesn't have to remember or re-enter what they already told the system.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Location and days are primary (the two hard constraints). Budget is secondary. Duration and amenities are tertiary. This mirrors the order in which the agent asked questions — location and days determine feasibility, everything else is filterable.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Compact single-line summary visible on all search/listing pages. Expandable to full profile on tap. Editable inline without navigating away from current page.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 5 parameters visible in compact mode. Full profile expands to show all parameters with edit controls.
exclude: Detailed amenity checklist in compact mode
Host preferences or lifestyle compatibility scores in search phase

elements.title: Weekly Stay Dashboard with Next-Action Prominence
elements.problem: During active lease, Tyler will have a repeating weekly cycle with occasional exceptions (holiday travel). The information architecture for the Stays Manager must prioritize 'what do I need to do next?' over 'what is the complete history of my lease?' Eyal's Trigger theory (Ch 2) shows that effective triggers tell the user exactly what action to take next. A dashboard that shows a full lease calendar is information-heavy but action-light. Tyler needs to see: 'This week: arriving Saturday Dec 6. Anything to update?' not 'Here is a 16-week calendar with all your stays.'
elements.solution: Structure the active lease view as a next-action dashboard: (1) PRIMARY: This Week's Stay — large, prominent card showing arrival date, any notes from host, and one-tap check-in action. (2) SECONDARY: Upcoming Changes — any date exceptions flagged (e.g., 'Dec 20-23: marked as traveling'). (3) TERTIARY: Stay History — past stays with review status and cleaning photo log. (4) EXPANDABLE: Full lease calendar for planning. The hierarchy is: next action → upcoming exceptions → history → full calendar. Each weekly cycle starts with the next-action card, which serves as the owned trigger that anchors the hook cycle.

evidence.quote: I'm going to be traveling for like three or four nights before Christmas.
evidence.insight: Exceptions to the weekly pattern need to be visible and manageable. The dashboard must surface upcoming exceptions prominently.

evidence.quote: An external trigger communicates the next action the user should take. Often, the desired action is made explicitly clear.
evidence.insight: The dashboard itself is a trigger. It must communicate the next action clearly: 'Check in for your Saturday stay' or 'Update your schedule for Christmas week.'

evidence.quote: Cleaning after yourself for the person, that person would be cleaning for you.
evidence.insight: End-of-stay actions (cleaning, photos) are part of the weekly cycle. The dashboard must show these as natural next actions, not buried in settings.

evidence.quote: Reducing the thinking required to take the next action increases the likelihood of the desired behavior occurring unconsciously.
evidence.insight: The dashboard must reduce cognitive load to one question: 'What do I need to do next?' Everything else is secondary.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Next action is primary (70% of visible space). Upcoming exceptions are secondary (visible but not dominant). History is tertiary (scrollable below the fold). Full calendar is hidden behind an 'expand' action.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Show only this week's stay card by default. Show upcoming exceptions if any exist. Reveal full history and calendar on scroll or tap. Never show the full 16-week calendar as the default view.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 items visible without scrolling: this week's stay card, one upcoming exception (if any), and a 'past stays' summary count. Full history requires scroll.
scan_order: This week's stay card with check-in action
Any flagged exceptions for upcoming weeks
Past stays summary (e.g., '3 stays completed, 2 reviewed')
exclude: Full lease calendar as default view
Payment details on the main dashboard (move to separate tab)
Complex date management tools on the main view — move to 'Edit Schedule' action

elements.title: Craigslist-to-Platform Bridge Information Sequence
elements.problem: Tyler discovered Split Lease through a Craigslist posting. When he transitions from Craigslist to Split Lease (either by clicking a link or by contacting the agent), he needs a specific information sequence that bridges the two contexts. Craigslist gave him: a listing, a price, a location. Split Lease needs to give him: what Split Lease is, why it's better than direct Craigslist transactions, and how to proceed. Currently, this bridge is the agent phone call — which is expensive, unscalable, and stores no data on the platform. Eyal's Trigger theory (Ch 2) shows that the external trigger (Craigslist listing) must clearly communicate the next action.
elements.solution: When a guest arrives from an external listing (Craigslist, Facebook Marketplace, etc.), present a targeted bridge sequence: (1) RECOGNITION: 'You found [Nina's Chelsea space] on Craigslist. Here's the full listing on Split Lease.' — confirm they're in the right place. (2) VALUE PROPOSITION: 'Split Lease handles scheduling, payments, and cleaning coordination so you and Nina don't have to.' — explain why the platform exists in one sentence. (3) NEXT ACTION: 'Tell us your preferred days and we'll check if this space works for your schedule.' — clear call to action that captures investment. (4) FALLBACK: 'Prefer to talk to someone? Call [agent] or chat with us.' — human option for those who need it. This sequence should take 15 seconds to scan, replacing a 15-minute phone call for the information-gathering portion.

evidence.quote: On Craigslist, I just clicked search for Chelsea. And then I saw that posting.
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model is 'I found a Craigslist listing.' The platform must connect to this mental model, not replace it.

evidence.quote: Basically what we do is split lists. We're trying to help multi locals to manage that difficult circumstance.
evidence.insight: The value proposition is explained verbally by the agent. It should be communicated visually on the platform's landing page for external arrivals.

evidence.quote: External triggers are embedded with information, which tells the user what to do next.
evidence.insight: The Craigslist listing is the trigger, but it must lead to a clear next action on Split Lease. Currently it leads to a phone call.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Recognition of the specific listing is primary (confirms the guest is in the right place). Value proposition is secondary (explains why Split Lease exists). Next action is tertiary but most important functionally (captures investment).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Single-page bridge: listing confirmation + value prop + day selector + fallback contact. No navigation required. No account creation required before this sequence.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 sections visible: listing confirmation, value proposition (one sentence), day/schedule selector, and contact fallback. Total reading time under 15 seconds.
scan_order: Listing photo and title from the external source
exclude: Full platform explanation or about page
Pricing details before the guest has selected their days
Other listings (focus on the one they came for)
